description:
Chlamydia abortus is a species of obligate intracellular bacteria that belongs to the genus Chlamydia. It is the causative agent of enzootic abortion in sheep and goats, a significant reproductive disease in these livestock animals.

Chlamydia abortus is a Gram-negative, small, spherical to ovoid-shaped bacterium that lacks a true cell wall. It has a distinctive biphasic developmental cycle, alternating between an infectious elementary body and a replicative reticulate body. The elementary bodies are the metabolically inactive and environmentally resistant form that can infect host cells, while the reticulate bodies are the metabolically active and dividing form within the host cell.

The bacterium primarily infects the placental trophoblast cells of the host, leading to placentitis, fetal death, and abortion in late gestation. Transmission can occur through direct contact with infected animals, their placental tissues, or contaminated environments. Chlamydia abortus can also cause zoonotic infections in humans, leading to flu-like symptoms and potential complications in pregnant women.

Diagnosis of Chlamydia abortus infection typically involves serological tests, such as enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA) or complement fixation tests, as well as molecular techniques like polymerase chain reaction (PCR) on clinical samples. Prevention and control measures focus on biosecurity, vaccination, and appropriate management practices in affected livestock herds.
